entry.title: Newsletter #81
entry.content:
It’s #TechThursday again!

It’s true that we are nerds but it’s also true that we are working for a fashion company.

This is one of our attempts to get more fashionable:

Here is the traditional “selection” of links our team found interesting this week , enjoy:

  • Using the HTML5 History API

  • What UX Can Learn from Print

  • Linux insides ebook

  • V8 – Experimental new directions for Javascript

  • Booboo: error handler for PHP

  • Debugging with PhpStorm

  • RedPen: an awesome visual feedback tool

  • 9 truths that computer programmers know that most people don’t

  • Google CFO retires with a candid memo about work/life balance

  • Numbers everyone should know

  • How many package managers should I support?

  • Multi-host docker network

  • Why this tech bubble is worse than the one in 2000

  • How can I simulate a slow machine in a VM?

  • Introducing Google Cloud Storage Nearline: (near)online data at an offline price

that’s all folks, see you next week! :)

entry.title: Newsletter #50
entry.content:
Hey folks! Hope you had a great week!

Announcement:

We are looking for a senior software engineer passionate about NodeJS and a frontend designer who is passionate and kick-ass in CSS and HTML and wants to expand his skillset with some JavaScript — we <3 javascript :)

We will detail in a separate post but, for the time being, feel free to reach out to submit your linkedin / github profile to work-in-tech@namshi.com

Here are your links for this week!

  • Mind-blowing facts about Google
  • Is TLS Fast Yet?
  • Amazon RDS Now Supports T2 Instances
  • The One Big Thing That Will Reduce Software Bugs, But No One Does It
  • CoreOS and Docker through Deis: Your Paas. Your Rules.
  • The Twelve-Factor App
  • Redis 3.0.0 beta 8 is out
  • Critiquing Facebook’s new #PHP spec
  • ideavim – plugin that let’s you use vim keybindings inside a intellj based ides (phpstorm/webstorm ide
  • A very old post, but still super good, about object oriented programming in JavaScript
  • Why does windows think that my wireless keyboard is a toaster
  • Game of Hacks
  • Why I think having passion as a developer matters
  • BadUSB what if you could never trust a USB device again
  • 3 security mistakes small companies make and how to avoid them
  • Track and Audit shipments for free
  • DConf 2014: Declarative programming in D by Mihails Strasuns aka Dicebot
  • Welcome to RocksDB!
  • Alerting Dashboard for Graphite
  • Why You Can’t Learn To Code Without Open Source
  • JavaScript Promises Are Cool
  • The Top Programming Languages in IEEE Spectrum’s 2014 Ranking
  • Building a Better PHP – Part 5: Static Analysis & other CLI tools
  • dotScale 2014 – Fabien Potencier – My Take on PHP

entry.title: Newsletter #40
entry.content:
TA-DA! TechThursday newsletter is here!

  • Object.observe will change everything you know about data binding. It’s the future.

  • PHP Next Generation

  • SOLID: Single Responsibility (SRP), Open/Close, Liskov’s Substitution, Interface Segregation, and Dependency Inversion.
    Five principles that should guide you every time you write code. Part#1, Part#2, Part#3, Part#4

  • 20 cool things you can do with a Raspberry Pi

  • MIT tackled Earth’s atmosphere to give the moon broadband

  • When should I not kill -9 a process?

  • Google Bot’s Recent improvements might revolutionize web development

  • Undo what you just did in Git

  • A hacker’s Guide to Git

  • Understanding the difference between $scope.$watch() and Attributes.$observe() in AngularJS

  • 20 Things I learned about browser and web: An interactive book by Google

  • Measuring the performance of local storage

  • Van Halen’s smart contract clauses

  • AWS introduces additional EBS encryption

  • Making games in Qatar

  • LoopBack, a new NodeJS framework

  • How was the HTML blink tag born?

  • Vagrant PhpStorm Tunnel, a cool vagrant plugin that it will forward all php calls to php in the Vagrant VM

  • The new iteration of PHP (read the comments) (for more drama you can read internals discussion on PHPNG)

  • Data Structures Succinctly ebook

  • The Repository Design Pattern (PHP)
